title: MRE11 lactylation: a linker between Warburg effect and DNA repair
content: Lysine lactylation is a recently discovered post-translational modification with emerging roles in both physiology and disease. A recent study published in Cell shows that lactate-induced lactylation of the homologous recombination (HR) protein meiotic recombination 11 results in HR hyperactivation and chemoresistance in cancer cells, establishing a previously unrecognized link between cellular metabolism and deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) damage repair and providing new insights into how altered glucose metabolism can impact DNA damage response in cancer.
